bestBHT.bht: Shalt thou be exalted, etc.? asks the commentary, hinting at a negative answer. The mention of hell and reference to Matthew 16:18 point to future judgment. The distinction between Hades and Gehenna is made, emphasizing that Hades is not permanent hell. Capernaum, once exalted, is warned of being thrust down to hell, showing divine judgment for those arrogant in their prosperity, assuming they are heaven's chosen ones.

Archibald T. Robertson: Shalt thou be exalted? (μη υψωθησηι;). Μη expects the answer No. The verb is future passive indicative second singular of υψοω, to lift up, a late verb from υψος, height."
Is it the tender memories of boyhood that keep from His lips the name of the arch-rejector (Luke 4:28 sqq.) Nazareth?
John Gill: And thou Capernaum, which art exalted to heaven... Shalt be thrust down into hell.
It was a famous port, commodiously situated by the sea of Tiberias; and... in an excellent temperament of the air, and watered with a most choice fountain.

Such who have lived in great plenty and pleasure in this life, and have thought themselves to be the favourites of heaven, and that they should enter there, shall be thrust down to hell by the arm of vengeance.

bhtAttempts.bht: Shalt thou be exalted, etc.? asks the commentary, indicating a rhetorical question with an implied negative answer. The mention of hell and reference to Matthew 16:18 guide us to understand that this verse is referring to a future judgment and punishment. The commentary also distinguishes between Hades and Gehenna, emphasizing that Hades is not eternal hell. The mention of Nazareth brings up the possibility that Jesus does not explicitly name the arch-rejector, revealing a tender memory of His own rejection. The verse warns Capernaum, a once exalted city, that it will be thrust down to hell, indicating a divine judgment for those who live in plenty and pride, thinking they are favored by heaven.

Shalt thou be exalted, etc.? asks the commentary, indicating a rhetorical question with an implied negative answer. The mention of hell and reference to Matthew 16:18 guide us to understand that this passage speaks of future judgment and punishment. The distinction between Hades and Gehenna is made, noting that Hades is not eternal hell. Capernaum, once exalted, is warned of being thrust down to hell, indicating divine judgment for those who live in pride and prosperity, presuming they are favored by heaven.

Shalt thou be exalted, etc.? asks the commentary, hinting at a negative answer. The mention of hell and reference to Matthew 16:18 point to future judgment. The distinction between Hades and Gehenna is made, emphasizing that Hades is not permanent hell. Capernaum, once exalted, is warned of being thrust down to hell, showing divine judgment for those arrogant in their prosperity, assuming they are heaven's chosen ones.

Shalt thou be exalted, etc.? asks the commentary, implying a negative response. The mention of hell and reference to Matthew 16:18 suggests a future judgment. Distinguishing Hades from Gehenna, the commentary clarifies that Hades is not everlasting hell. Capernaum is warned that its exalted status will be overturned, thrusting it down to hell. This serves as a reminder that those who live lavishly and presume to be favored by heaven will face the wrath of divine retribution.
